name: Django Cheatsheet
description: To list the Django Mostly Used Functionality .Which will be beneficial for the Extensive Django Users/Developers

Django Admin/Manage.py Commands.val: display usage information and a list of the commands provided by each application
display a list of all available commands
display  description of command
show version
inspect the entire Django project for common problems
creates a superuser account
command-line client for the database engine
Displays differences between the current settings file and Django’s default settings
standard output all data in the database associated with the named application
Removes all data from the database
script will inspect the database and create a model for each table within it
Runs over the entire source tree of the current directory and pulls out all strings marked for translation
Creates new migrations based on the changes detected to your models
synchronizes the database state with the current set of models and migrations
Starts a lightweight development Web server on the local machine
Sends a test mail to the recipients
Starts the Python interactive interpreter
Shows all migrations in a project
Prints the SQL statements that would be executed for the flush command
Prints the SQL for the named migration
Creates a Django app directory structure for the given app name in the current directory or the given destination
Creates a Django project directory structure for the given project name in the current directory or the given destination
Runs tests for all installed apps.
Runs tests for all installed apps.

QuerySet Commands.val: Returns a new QuerySet containing objects that match the given lookup parameters
Returns a new QuerySet containing objects that do not match the given lookup parameters
Results returned by a QuerySet are ordered by the ordering tuple given by the ordering option in the model’s Meta
reverse the order in which a queryset’s elements are returned
Returns a new QuerySet that uses SELECT DISTINCT in its SQL query
Returns a QuerySet that returns dictionaries, rather than model instances, when used as an iterable
Returns tuples when iterated over
Returns a QuerySet that evaluates to a list of datetime.datetime objects representing all available dates of a particular kind within the contents of the QuerySet
will create a queryset that never returns any objects
Returns a copy of the current QuerySet
Returns a QuerySet that will “follow” foreign-key relationships
Returns a QuerySet that will automatically retrieve, in a single batch, related objects for each of the specified lookups
Takes a raw SQL query, executes it, and returns a django.db.models.query.RawQuerySet instance
Returns the object matching the given lookup parameters
Method for creating an object and saving it all in one step
A convenience method for looking up an object with the given kwargs (may be empty if your model has defaults for all fields), creating one if necessary
This method inserts the provided list of objects into the database in an efficient manner
Returns an integer representing the number of objects in the database matching the QuerySet
Returns the latest object in the table
Works otherwise like latest() except the direction is changed
Returns the first object matched by the queryset
Returns the last object matched by the queryset
Returns a dictionary of aggregate values (averages, sums, etc.)
Returns True if the QuerySet contains any results
Performs an SQL update query for the specified fields
Performs an SQL delete query
Performs an SQL save query
Performs an SQL save query

Field LookUps.val: For datetime fields, casts the value as date
For date and datetime fields, an exact year match
For date and datetime fields, an exact month match
For date and datetime fields, an exact day match
For date and datetime fields, a ‘day of the week’ match
For datetime and time fields, an exact hour match
For datetime and time fields, an exact minute match
For datetime and time fields, an exact second match
Takes either True or False, which correspond to SQL queries of IS NULL and IS NOT NULL, respectively
Boolean full-text search, taking advantage of full-text indexing
